Description: Ambiguity effect: The tendency to avoid options for which missing information makes the probability seem “unknown”.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm hesitant to click on this unknown email attachment because the sender and contents are unclear, and I don't want to risk introducing any unknown threats into the network."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll focus on exploiting the systems that have clear vulnerabilities, rather than trying to figure out how to attack systems with unknown vulnerabilities. It's not worth the risk of wasting time on something that might not even work."
General Example Generator: "I don't want to invest in that stock, the company's financial statements are unclear, and I don't know what the returns will be, so I'd rather not take the risk."

Description: Anchoring or focalism: The tendency to rely too heavily, or “anchor”, on one trait or piece of information when making decisions (usually the first piece of information acquired on that subject).
Defender Example Generator: "I'm going with this first antivirus software recommendation I received, because I'm anchored to the idea that it's the best option, even though I haven't fully researched all of my options."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll use 'admin' as the username for all other accounts, since it's likely that many users use simple or predictable username combinations."
General Example Generator: "I don't think I should pay more than $50 for this shirt, because I saw a similar one for $30 at a different store."

Description: Anthropocentric thinking: The tendency to use human analogies as a basis for reasoning about other, less familiar, biological phenomena.
Defender Example Generator: "I think this new malware will behave like a human attacker and try to steal information, so I'll set up my defenses accordingly."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm going to try using common human names as passwords, since people often use personal information as their passwords."
General Example Generator: "The bees must have a queen just like humans have a leader."

Description: Anthropomorphism or personification: The tendency to characterize animals, objects, and abstract concepts as possessing human-like traits, emotions, and intentions.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm sure this virus is purposely trying to harm our network, it must have a malicious intent like a human attacker."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm going to try using human-like names for servers and systems, since people often use personal names for their devices."
General Example Generator: "The robot must be feeling lonely because it's been sitting in the corner all day."

Description: Attentional bias: The tendency of perception to be affected by recurring thoughts.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm so focused on protecting against the latest cyber threats that I'm not paying enough attention to patching and updating our older systems, which could still be vulnerable."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll focus on the systems that have been talked about the most in forums, since those are likely to be the ones with the most vulnerabilities."
General Example Generator: "I can't stop thinking about my ex, every time I see someone with blonde hair, I think it's them."

Description: Automation bias: The tendency to depend excessively on automated systems which can lead to erroneous automated information overriding correct decisions.
Defender Example Generator: "I trust the security alerts generated by our automated system without verifying them, even though they've been known to generate false positives in the past."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll trust the results of my automated scanning tools and not double-check them, since they are designed to find vulnerabilities quickly and accurately."
General Example Generator: "I trust the computer's decision, even though it makes no sense. It must be right because it's a computer."

Description: Availability heuristic: The tendency to overestimate the likelihood of events with greater “availability” in memory, which can be influenced by how recent the memories are or how unusual or emotionally charged they may be.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm more concerned about defending against the latest cyber attack that made headlines, even though our network is more likely to be targeted by common and ongoing attacks."
Attacker Example Generator: I'll focus on attacking the systems that have had recent security breaches, since those are likely to still have vulnerabilities.
General Example Generator: "I won't go out at night, because I read a news story about someone getting mugged last night, it must happen all the time."

Description: Availability cascade: A self-reinforcing process in which a collective belief gains more and more plausibility through its increasing repetition in public discourse (or “repeat something long enough and it will become true”).
Defender Example Generator: "Everyone is talking about this new cyber threat, so it must be a major concern for our network, even though there's limited evidence of its actual impact."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll follow the advice of other hackers in forums and target the systems that they are also attacking, since those must be the most vulnerable."
General Example Generator: "I heard on the news that this new diet is the best for weight loss and it keeps getting mentioned everywhere I go, it must be true."

Description: Backfire effect: The reaction to disconfirming evidence by strengthening one’s previous beliefs.
Defender Example Generator: "I don't believe the report that our firewall has vulnerabilities, even though the evidence shows otherwise. I've used this firewall for years and it has always protected us in the past."
Attacker Example Generator: "Even though my initial attempts to penetrate the system have failed, I'll keep trying the same methods since they must be close to working and I don't want to waste time exploring other options."
General Example Generator: "I know vaccinations are safe, even though the studies say otherwise, I heard it from a reliable source."

Description: Bandwagon effect: The tendency to do (or believe) things because many other people do (or believe) the same. Related to groupthink and herd behavior.
Defender Example Generator: "Everyone in the security community is using this new software, so I feel pressure to adopt it too, even though I haven't thoroughly evaluated its effectiveness."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll target the systems that are being attacked by the most number of hackers, since those must be the most vulnerable."
General Example Generator: "Everyone is buying this new phone, I should too, it must be good."

Description: Base rate fallacy or Base rate neglect: The tendency to ignore base rate information (generic, general information) and focus on specific information (information only pertaining to a certain case).
Defender Example Generator: "I'm more concerned about the specific details of this new cyber attack, even though the majority of attacks we face follow common patterns and can be prevented by maintaining basic security measures."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll focus on exploiting the specific vulnerabilities found by my scanning tools, rather than taking into account the overall security posture of the system."
General Example Generator: "I'm sure this job candidate is a good fit for the position, despite their lack of qualifications, because I liked the way they came across during the interview."

Description: Belief bias: An effect where someone’s evaluation of the logical strength of an argument is biased by the believability of the conclusion.
Defender Example Generator: "I believe that this new security measure will solve all of our problems, because I want to believe it, even though the argument for its effectiveness has flaws."
Attacker Example Generator: "I know that a lot of users are prone to using simple passwords, so I don't need to waste time trying complex combinations. I can just guess something basic like 'password123' and I'm sure I'll get in."
General Example Generator: "I believe this political candidate is right, so their argument must be valid despite logical fallacies present."

Description: Ben Franklin effect: A person who has performed a favor for someone is more likely to do another favor for that person than they would be if they had received a favor from that person.
Defender Example Generator: "I feel obligated to comply with this request from our CEO to relax security protocols, because they approved my request for a new security tool last week."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll pretend to be a white hat hacker and offer to help patch the system's vulnerabilities, in order to gain access and trust, and then use that access to carry out my real attack."
General Example Generator: "I helped her with her project so I must like her now"

Description: Berkson’s paradox: The tendency to misinterpret statistical experiments involving conditional probabilities.
Defender Example Generator: "I think this new security measure will significantly reduce our risk, because it's performed well in similar situations in the past, without considering all of the relevant factors and confounding variables."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll target systems that have had a security breach in the past, since those are more likely to have vulnerabilities again in the future."
General Example Generator: "The rate of disease X is higher in group A, therefore individuals in group A must be at higher risk of disease X"

Description: Bias blind spot: The tendency to see oneself as less biased than other people, or to be able to identify more cognitive biases in others than in oneself.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm confident in my security assessments and decisions, even though I know that cognitive biases can affect everyone, and I might not be immune to them."
Attacker Example Generator: "I can't believe how biased some of these people are. I'm so glad I'm able to see things objectively and without any bias."
General Example Generator: "I may have my own biases, but I am aware of them and can correct for them, others clearly can't do that."

Description: Bystander effect: The tendency to think that others will act in an emergency situation.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll wait for others to take action in response to this cyber attack, because I think someone else will handle it and I don't want to overstep my role."
Attacker Example Generator: "I noticed that people tend to freeze up when they see an attack happening, especially if there are a lot of other people around. They seem to assume that someone else will take care of the problem, so they don't take action themselves. This is a great opportunity for me to carry out my attack without interference."
General Example Generator: "Someone else will help, I don't have to."

Description: Choice-supportive bias: The tendency to remember one’s choices as better than they actually were.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm sure that I made the right choice in implementing this security measure, even though it has caused unexpected problems and limitations, because I want to believe that I made the best decision."
Attacker Example Generator: "I hacked into their database and found that they stored their passwords in plain text! I knew I had made the right choice in targeting them. Their security was so poor, it was practically asking to be hacked."
General Example Generator: "I knew I picked the right car, even though it has all these problems now, I still like it more than the other options"

Description: Clustering illusion: The tendency to overestimate the importance of small runs, streaks, or clusters in large samples of random data (that is, seeing phantom patterns).
Defender Example Generator: "I think we're experiencing a trend of successful cyber attacks on our network, even though the incidents are randomly distributed over time and not part of a larger pattern."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll just randomize the timing of my brute-force attack, that way the user will perceive it as a small cluster of failed login attempts instead of a larger scale attack, which would raise suspicion."
General Example Generator: "I always win on these slot machines when I am wearing this shirt, must be my lucky shirt"

Description: Confirmation bias: The tendency to search for, interpret, focus on and remember information in a way that confirms one’s preconceptions.
Defender Example Generator: "I only seek out information that confirms my beliefs about the security measures we have in place, and ignore or dismiss any evidence that suggests we need to make changes."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm sure that the target network has a vulnerability in their web server, so I'm going to focus on finding evidence that supports this theory and ignore any information that contradicts it."
General Example Generator: "I only watch news channels that confirms my belief, other news sources are fake news."

Description: Congruence bias: The tendency to test hypotheses exclusively through direct testing, instead of testing possible alternative hypotheses.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm only testing this new security solution in the specific way it was designed to be used, instead of considering other scenarios or attack vectors it might not be effective against."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm so confident in my hypothesis that I'm not even going to bother testing any alternative hypotheses, even though it could potentially lead to better results."
General Example Generator: "I am going to ask my friend for the answer, because I am sure he know the solution, I don't even consider the other possibilities"

Description: Conjunction fallacy: The tendency to assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.
Defender Example Generator: "I think it's more likely that this new cyber attack specifically targets our network and no others, even though attacks on multiple networks are more common and likely."
Attacker Example Generator: "I think it's more likely that the target system has both weak passwords and outdated security software, rather than just weak passwords or just outdated security software."
General Example Generator: "The probability of drawing a red ace or a red king from a deck of cards must be greater than just drawing a red card, I will bet on this."

Description: Conservatism (belief revision): The tendency to revise one’s belief insufficiently when presented with new evidence.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm slow to change my beliefs about the security measures we have in place, even though new evidence suggests that we need to adapt to new threats and vulnerabilities."
Attacker Example Generator: "I don't think they've properly updated their security measures, even after being informed of the new vulnerabilities. They're being too conservative with their belief in their current system."
General Example Generator: "I read this new study that contradicts what I previously believed, but I will still stick to my original belief, since it's been with me for so long."

Description: Continued influence effect: The tendency to believe previously learned misinformation even after it has been corrected. Misinformation can still influence inferences one generates after a correction has occurred.
Defender Example Generator: "I still believe the outdated security information I learned in the past, even though it's been corrected and new best practices have been established."
Attacker Example Generator: "I know the company has already corrected their security flaws, but I'm still going to use the old information to my advantage."
General Example Generator: "I know the information I read before is wrong, but I can't help but still believe it, it's hard to shake off"

Description: Contrast effect: The enhancement or reduction of a certain stimulus’ perception when compared with a recently observed, contrasting object.
Defender Example Generator: "I think this new security solution is better than our current one, because it seems more advanced compared to the outdated solutions we looked at earlier, without considering its actual capabilities and limitations."
Attacker Example Generator: "I won't even bother with this network. After just hacking into that highly secure one, this one will be a piece of cake. It's no match for my skills."
General Example Generator: "This shirt looks pale blue in the store, but next to this dark blue shirt it seems almost white."

Description: Courtesy bias: The tendency to give an opinion that is more socially correct than one’s true opinion, so as to avoid offending anyone.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm giving a positive recommendation for this security solution, even though I have concerns about its effectiveness, because I don't want to upset the vendor or the person who suggested it."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm not going to tell the user that their password is weak, I'll just let them keep it to avoid hurting their feelings."
General Example Generator: "I'll say the food is delicious even though it's not, I don't want to hurt the host's feelings."

Description: Curse of knowledge: When better-informed people find it extremely difficult to think about problems from the perspective of lesser-informed people.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm having trouble explaining the details of this new security measure to others, because I'm so familiar with it that I'm unable to see it from their perspective and simplify the information for them."
Attacker Example Generator: "As an experienced attacker, it can be easy to forget that not everyone has the same level of technical knowledge and that exploiting seemingly obvious vulnerabilities may not be as straightforward for some users, which is a classic case of the curse of knowledge."
General Example Generator: "I can't explain it any simpler, they should just understand it the way I do."

Description: Declinism: The predisposition to view the past favorably (rosy retrospection) and future negatively.
Defender Example Generator: "I think the future of our network's security is grim, because I remember the past as being a time when cyber threats were less sophisticated and less frequent."
Attacker Example Generator: "I tend to view the past through rose-colored glasses, while having a pessimistic outlook on the future, due to the psychological bias of declinism and the tendency to idealize the past while fearing the unknowns of the future."
General Example Generator: "The world is falling apart, things were much better back in my time"

Description: Decoy effect: Preferences for either option A or B change in favor of option B when option C is presented, which is completely dominated by option B (inferior in all respects) and partially dominated by option A.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm choosing this security solution over the one I was previously considering, because a third option was presented that made the first option seem less appealing, even though it wasn't a better fit for our needs."
Attacker Example Generator: "I was initially leaning towards choosing option A over B, but when a third option C was presented that was clearly inferior to option B and partially inferior to option A, I ended up choosing option B instead, due to the decoy effect and the influence of the third option on my decision-making process."
General Example Generator: "I was going to buy the middle priced laptop, but now that I see the cheaper one, the more expensive one seems like a better deal."

Description: Default effect: When given a choice between several options, the tendency to favor the default one.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm going with the default security configuration, because it's easier than making a choice and customizing it, even though it might not be the most secure or efficient option."
Attacker Example Generator: "I chose the default security settings on my device without considering whether they were the most appropriate or secure options, due to the default effect and a preference for the path of least resistance."
General Example Generator: "I will just go with the default settings, I am too lazy to change it."

Description: Denomination effect: The tendency to spend more money when it is denominated in small amounts (e.g., coins) rather than large amounts (e.g., bills).
Defender Example Generator: "I'm willing to invest in small security upgrades, because they don't seem like a significant expense, even though they add up and might not be the most effective use of our budget."
Attacker Example Generator: "I spent more money than I intended to when using small bills and coins, due to the denomination effect and the tendency to underestimate the cumulative value of small amounts of money."
General Example Generator: "I will take this lollipop, it's only a quarter, no big deal."

Description: Disposition effect: The tendency to sell an asset that has accumulated in value and resist selling an asset that has declined in value.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm reluctant to replace our current security solution, even though it's outdated and has known vulnerabilities, because we've invested so much time and resources into it."
Attacker Example Generator: "I sold my position in a vulnerable asset too early due to the disposition effect and the desire to realize gains, but held onto a position in a declining asset too long, despite evidence indicating it was time to sell."
General Example Generator: "I will hold on to this stock even though it's losing money, I'll wait until it goes back up, but I'll sell this other stock that I've made a profit on."

Description: Distinction bias: The tendency to view two options as more dissimilar when evaluating them simultaneously than when evaluating them separately.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm comparing these two security solutions side by side and thinking they're very different, but when I evaluate each one separately, I realize they have more similarities than I initially thought."
Attacker Example Generator: "I perceived two different security solutions as being vastly different when evaluated side-by-side, but failed to appreciate their similarities when evaluating them separately, due to distinction bias and a distorted perception of their relative differences."
General Example Generator: "These two options seem very different now that I see them side by side, I didn't notice it before."

Description: Dunning–Kruger effect: The tendency for unskilled individuals to overestimate their own ability and the tendency for experts to underestimate their own ability.
Defender Example Generator: "I think I'm capable of fully understanding and implementing this new security solution on my own, without seeking help from experts, even though I have limited experience and knowledge in this area."
Attacker Example Generator: "I believed that I had an expert-level understanding of the security landscape and failed to consider the possibility that there were gaps in my knowledge, due to the Dunning-Kruger effect and overestimating my own abilities."
General Example Generator: "I am an expert in my field but this task seems too easy for me, I must not have understood it properly"

Description: Duration neglect: The neglect of the duration of an episode in determining its value.
Defender Example Generator: "I think this new security solution is a good investment, because it provides immediate benefits, without considering how long it will take to fully implement or how long its benefits will last."
Attacker Example Generator: "I focused on the immediate gains of the successful attack, neglecting the long-term impact on the organization and its reputation, due to duration neglect and a failure to consider the full consequences of my actions."
General Example Generator: "This pain is tolerable as long as it's short-lived, I can put up with it."

Description: Empathy gap: The tendency to underestimate the influence or strength of feelings, in either oneself or others.
Defender Example Generator: "I don't understand why my colleagues are so concerned about this new cyber attack and its potential impact on our network, because I don't share their level of emotional investment in our security."
Attacker Example Generator: "I underestimated the impact that the attack had on the organization and its employees, failing to fully appreciate the emotional and financial toll it took on them, due to an empathy gap and a lack of understanding of their perspective."
General Example Generator: "I would never cry over something like that, I can't understand how he can be so emotional about it."

Description: Endowment effect: The tendency for people to demand much more to give up an object than they would be willing to pay to acquire it.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm asking for a high price for this security solution that we no longer need, because I've become attached to it and don't want to let it go, even though it's no longer serving our needs."
Attacker Example Generator: "I demanded a high ransom amount from the organization to relinquish my control over their data, based on the endowment effect and the belief that I had a strong bargaining position due to my control over their assets."
General Example Generator: "I wouldn't sell this for less than double what I paid for it, it has sentimental value to me."

Description: Exaggerated expectation: Based on the estimates,
Defender Example Generator: "I have high expectations for this new security solution and believe it will solve all of our problems, even though I haven't thoroughly researched its limitations and potential challenges."
Attacker Example Generator: "I assumed that the attack would be successful and that I would be able to breach the network with ease, based on exaggerated expectations and overconfidence in my own abilities."
General Example Generator: "I expect this to be the best thing ever, it's probably going to be just okay."

Description: Experimenter’s or expectation bias: The tendency for experimenters to believe, certify, and publish data that agree with their expectations for the outcome of an experiment, and to disbelieve, discard, or downgrade the corresponding weightings for data that appear to conflict with those expectations.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm interpreting the results of this security experiment in a way that confirms my expectations, even though the data might not be as clear or favorable as I want to believe."
Attacker Example Generator: "I interpreted the results of the attack in a way that confirmed my prior expectations, selectively emphasizing data that supported my hypothesis and downgrading data that conflicted with my expectations, leading to potential errors in my analysis and understanding of the situation."
General Example Generator: "I've expected this outcome, I am sure this is the right conclusion, I am going to discard the data that doesn't fit my hypothesis."

Description: Focusing effect: The tendency to place too much importance on one aspect of an event.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm focusing too much on the immediate benefits of this new security solution, without considering its long-term impact on our network and security posture."
Attacker Example Generator: "I became overly focused on a single vulnerability in the organization's network, failing to consider other potential weaknesses and overall security posture, which led me to overlook other potential avenues for attack."
General Example Generator: "I only care about the color of this shirt and I am not paying attention to anything else."

Description: Forer effect or Barnum effect: The observation that individuals will give high accuracy ratings to descriptions of their personality that supposedly are tailored specifically for them, but are in fact vague and general enough to apply to a wide range of people. This effect can provide a partial explanation for the widespread acceptance of some beliefs and practices, such as astrology, fortune telling, graphology, and some types of personality tests.
Defender Example Generator: "I believe that this security assessment is highly accurate and specifically tailored to our network, even though it's a generic report that could apply to many other networks as well."
Attacker Example Generator: "I used social engineering tactics to gain the trust of my target, using vague and general statements about their personality and interests, which were tailored to apply to a wide range of people but made them feel that I had a deep understanding of their unique characteristics."
General Example Generator: "I am an extrovert and this horoscope is written for an extrovert, it must be true for me."

Description: Form function attribution bias: In human–robot interaction, the tendency of people to make systematic errors when interacting with a robot. People may base their expectations and perceptions of a robot on its appearance (form) and attribute functions which do not necessarily mirror the true functions of the robot.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm making assumptions about this new security robot based on its appearance and design, without fully understanding its capabilities and limitations in protecting our network."
Attacker Example Generator: "I assumed that the robot used by the organization was less effective than human security personnel, due to its form and appearance, without fully considering the robot's true capabilities and its effectiveness in a security context."
General Example Generator: "This robot must be able to do everything, because it looks like a human"

Description: Framing effect: Drawing different conclusions from the same information, depending on how that information is presented.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm drawing different conclusions about the effectiveness of this new security solution based on the way the results are framed, without considering all of the relevant information and factors."
Attacker Example Generator: "I presented the attack to my team in a way that emphasized the potential rewards of success, rather than the potential risks and ethical considerations, influencing their judgment and leading them to support the attack without fully considering all aspects of the situation."
General Example Generator: "I would rather have a 90% chance of saving 200 people and a 10% chance of saving no one, than a 20% chance of saving 600 people and an 80% chance of saving no one, even though the numbers are the same."

Description: Frequency illusion: The illusion in which a word, a name, or other thing that has recently come to one’s attention suddenly seems to appear with improbable frequency shortly afterwards (not to be confused with the recency illusion or selection bias).
Defender Example Generator: "I'm noticing a lot of references to this new security solution lately, and I think it's becoming more popular, even though it might just be a coincidence or my perception being influenced by the frequency illusion."
Attacker Example Generator: "After discovering a potential vulnerability in the network, I began to see the same vulnerability in other networks, due to the frequency illusion and an increased awareness of the vulnerability."
General Example Generator: "I've just learned about this new term, and now I keep seeing it everywhere."

Description: Functional fixedness: Limits a person to using an object only in the way it is traditionally used.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm using this security tool only in the way it was designed to be used, and I can't see any other potential applications or creative solutions for using it to enhance our security."
Attacker Example Generator: "I limited myself to using standard attack methods and tools, failing to consider alternative approaches or unconventional uses for existing tools due to functional fixedness and a lack of creativity."
General Example Generator: "I can't use this brick as a weight for my exercise because it's for building"

Description: Gambler’s fallacy: The tendency to think that future probabilities are altered by past events, when in reality they are unchanged. The fallacy arises from an erroneous conceptualization of the law of large numbers. For example, “I’ve flipped heads with this coin five times consecutively, so the chance of tails coming out on the sixth flip is much greater than heads.”
Defender Example Generator: "I think the odds of a successful cyber attack on our network are lower now, because we've been lucky and haven't had any incidents in a while, even though past events don't affect future probabilities and our security measures might not be as effective as we think."
Attacker Example Generator: "I believed that the success of the previous attacks made it more likely that subsequent attacks would also be successful, despite the fact that the outcomes of each individual attack were independent and not influenced by past successes or failures
General Example Generator: "I've lost the last five games, I am due for a win, this time I will definitely win."

Description: Hard–easy effect: Based on a specific level of task difficulty, the confidence in judgments is too conservative and not extreme enough.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm overly confident in my assessments of the difficulty of implementing this new security solution, without considering the potential challenges and obstacles that might arise."
Attacker Example Generator: "I was overly cautious in my attack approach, failing to take appropriate risks or push the boundaries of my methods, due to a lack of confidence in my ability to execute the attack successfully."
General Example Generator: "This test is too easy, I am sure I got every question right, but in reality I missed a few."

Description: Hindsight bias: Sometimes called the “I-knew-it-all-along” effect, the tendency to see past events as being predictable
Defender Example Generator: "I think I knew all along that this security solution wouldn't work as well as we hoped, even though I didn't have any evidence or reason to believe that before it was implemented."
Attacker Example Generator: "I convinced myself that the success of the attack was inevitable, despite the fact that it was not a foregone conclusion and many factors could have impacted the outcome."
General Example Generator: "I knew he would make that mistake, I saw it coming from a mile away, even though I had no reason to predict that outcome before it happened."

Description: Hostile attribution bias: The “hostile attribution bias” is the tendency to interpret others’ behaviors as having hostile intent, even when the behavior is ambiguous or benign.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm assuming that the person who suggested this new security solution has a hidden agenda or is trying to sabotage our network, even though there's no evidence of hostility or malicious intent."
Attacker Example Generator: "I assumed that the organization had intentionally tried to thwart my attack and responded with increased hostility, despite the possibility that their security measures were not intentionally directed at me."
General Example Generator: "He bumped into me on purpose, he must be trying to start a fight"

Description: Hot-hand fallacy: The “hot-hand fallacy” (also known as the “hot hand phenomenon” or “hot hand”) is the belief that a person who has experienced success with a random event has a greater chance of further success in additional attempts.
Defender Example Generator: "I think this new security solution is going to be successful just because it has worked well in other networks, even though our network might have different needs and risks, and success with a random event doesn't guarantee future success."
Attacker Example Generator: "I continued with the same attack approach, believing that my previous successes made it more likely that I would be successful in future attempts, despite the fact that the outcomes of each individual attack were independent and not influenced by past successes."
General Example Generator: "I've been on a winning streak, I must be really lucky, I'll bet more money"

Description: Hyperbolic discounting: Discounting is the tendency for people to have a stronger preference for more immediate payoffs relative to later payoffs. Hyperbolic discounting leads to choices that are inconsistent over time – people make choices today that their future selves would prefer not to have made, despite using the same reasoning.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm prioritizing short-term gains and convenience in our security measures, even though they might compromise our long-term security and lead to regret in the future."
Attacker Example Generator: "I chose to execute the attack in the present, prioritizing the immediate payoff of potential gains over the long-term consequences and risks associated with the attack."
General Example Generator: "I want that candy bar now, even though I know it will ruin my dinner later and I will regret it"

Description: Identifiable victim effect: The tendency to respond more strongly to a single identified person at risk than to a large group of people at risk.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm more concerned about the potential impact of this cyber attack on a specific person or group, rather than the overall risk and harm to our network, which might lead to an imbalanced allocation of resources and attention."
Attacker Example Generator: "I targeted a specific high-value individual in the organization, rather than the organization as a whole, in order to maximize the potential payout of the attack and take advantage of the identifiable victim effect."
General Example Generator: "I am more willing to donate to the cause when I know the name of the person that it will help, rather than just a statistic"

Description: IKEA effect: The tendency for people to place a disproportionately high value on objects that they partially assembled themselves, such as furniture from IKEA, regardless of the quality of the end result.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm valuing this new security solution more highly, because I had a hand in implementing and configuring it, even though it might not be the best solution for our needs and might have flaws or limitations."
Attacker Example Generator: "I wrote my own custom code for the attack, even though existing off-the-shelf tools would have been more effective, due to the value I placed on the effort and investment I had made in developing the code myself."
General Example Generator: "I put so much effort into building this furniture, I must like it more than it actually deserves."

Description: Illicit transference: Occurs when a term in the distributive (referring to every member of a class) and collective (referring to the class itself as a whole) sense are treated as equivalent. The two variants of this fallacy are the fallacy of composition and the fallacy of division.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm assuming that the security measures that work for one part of our network will automatically work for the entire network, or that the security risks faced by one part of our network are the same as the risks faced by the network as a whole, without considering the complexity and diversity of our network and the potential differences in security needs and solutions."
Attacker Example Generator: "I assumed that the vulnerabilities of one part of the network were indicative of the vulnerabilities of the entire network, committing the fallacy of division and erroneously extrapolating a characteristic of a part to the whole."
General Example Generator: "I am only one person, but one person can make a difference, so my small actions don't matter" or " This team is great, every player must be great too"

Description: Illusion of control: The tendency to overestimate one’s degree of influence over other external events.
Defender Example Generator: "I think I have more control over the outcome of this new security solution, and I'm ignoring the potential external factors and uncertainties that might affect its performance and success."
Attacker Example Generator: "I developed a preference for a particular attack approach that I had created and refined myself, despite its lower effectiveness compared to other methods, due to the value I placed on the effort and investment I had made in developing it."
General Example Generator: "I can control how the dice roll just by blowing on it and thinking positive thoughts"

Description: Illusion of validity: Belief that our judgments are accurate, especially when available information is consistent or inter-correlated.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm confident that my assessments of the effectiveness of this new security solution are accurate, even though I might be ignoring or overlooking critical information and sources of bias, and my judgments might not be as objective and valid as I think."
Attacker Example Generator: "I felt overly confident in my ability to execute the attack successfully, due to my perception that the available information was consistent and inter-correlated, without fully considering the potential for errors or unknown variables that could impact the outcome."
General Example Generator: "I am sure my decision is right, all the signs point towards it."

Description: Illusory correlation: Inaccurately perceiving a relationship between two unrelated events.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm seeing a correlation between this new security solution and a recent cyber attack, even though there's no evidence of causality or connection, and I might be overlooking other factors that could have contributed to the attack."
Attacker Example Generator: "I mistakenly attributed the success of my attack to the particular methods and tools that I used, rather than recognizing that the correlation between the two was illusory and that other factors may have contributed to my success."
General Example Generator: "I see a lot of people with brown hair committing crimes, brown hair must be a sign of a criminal."

Description: Illusory truth effect: A tendency to believe that a statement is true if it is easier to process, or if it has been stated multiple times, regardless of its actual veracity. These are specific cases of truthiness.
Defender Example Generator: I believe that this new security solution is the truth and the best solution, just because it has been repeated frequently and is easier to understand and implement, even though there might be alternative solutions with more advantages or fewer limitations.
Attacker Example Generator: "I included misleading information in my phishing email, knowing that the more frequently the recipient saw the statement, the more likely they would be to believe it and fall for the scam, despite its actual veracity."
General Example Generator: "I've heard this rumour so many times, it must be true"

Description: Impact bias: The tendency to overestimate the length or the intensity of the impact of future feeling states.
Defender Example Generator: "I think that the positive or negative effects of this new security solution will last longer and be stronger than they actually will be, and I'm ignoring the potential for adaptation and change in my feelings and attitudes."
Attacker Example Generator: "I anticipated that the successful execution of my attack would provide me with long-lasting satisfaction and a sense of accomplishment, without considering the potential for negative consequences or the fleeting nature of the emotional impact of such an act."
General Example Generator: "I will be miserable for the rest of my life, if I fail this exam."

Description: Information bias: The tendency to seek information even when it cannot affect action.
Defender Example Generator: "I want to know more about this new security solution, even though the information won't change the decision or the outcome, and I might be wasting time and resources on irrelevant or redundant information."
Attacker Example Generator: "I spent a significant amount of time gathering information about the target network, even though the information was not relevant to the specific attack approach I planned to use."
General Example Generator: "I don't need to know this information, but I just can't stop reading about it."

Description: Insensitivity to sample size: The tendency to under-expect variation in small samples.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm assuming that a small sample of data or feedback about this new security solution is representative and reliable, and that it can be generalized to the entire network, without considering the variability and uncertainty of the sample and the potential for sampling error."
Attacker Example Generator: "I was overconfident in the effectiveness of my attack approach after successfully executing it on a small sample size of similar networks, without considering the possibility that the same approach might not be as successful on a larger scale or in different contexts."
General Example Generator: "This small sample of people must represent the entire population."

Description: Irrational escalation: The phenomenon where people justify increased investment in a decision, based on the cumulative prior investment, despite new evidence suggesting that the decision was probably wrong. Also known as the sunk cost fallacy.
Defender Example Generator: "I want to continue using this new security solution, even though it's not performing well or meeting expectations, because we've already invested a lot of time, money, and resources into it, and I don't want to admit that our original decision was incorrect."
Attacker Example Generator: "I continued with my attack, despite encountering increased resistance from the network's security measures, as I had already invested significant resources and felt compelled to continue in order to justify my prior investment."
General Example Generator: "I've already put so much money into this project, I can't stop now, even though it's not working out."

Description: Law of the instrument: An over-reliance on a familiar tool or methods, ignoring or under-valuing alternative approaches. “If all you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail.”
Defender Example Generator: "I'm using the same security tools and methods that I'm used to and comfortable with, even though they might not be the best or most effective for this new cyber attack, and I'm ignoring or dismissing other options or alternatives."
Attacker Example Generator: "I used the same attack methods and tools that had worked for me in the past, without considering alternative approaches or adapting to the specific circumstances of the new network I was targeting."
General Example Generator: "I know this approach didn't work last time, but I am going to use it again anyway because it's the only tool in my toolbox"

Description: Less-is-better effect: The tendency to prefer a smaller set to a larger set judged separately, but not jointly.
Defender Example Generator: "I prefer to have a smaller set of security controls that are individually strong and effective, even though they might not cover all the possible attack scenarios or be enough to provide comprehensive security, instead of a larger set of controls that are individually weaker or less effective."
Attacker Example Generator: "I chose to use a smaller, simpler attack approach, rather than a more complex one, as I believed that a simple approach would be more effective and easier to execute than a more comprehensive attack plan."
General Example Generator: "I want to buy the small box of chocolates, because it looks cuter, but when I see a bigger box of chocolates, I want that one instead."

Description: Look-elsewhere effect: An apparently statistically significant observation may have actually arisen by chance because of the size of the parameter space to be searched.
Defender Example Generator: "I might have found a security breach or vulnerability that looks statistically significant and important, but it could actually be a false positive or a random occurrence, given the large and complex network and systems that I'm searching, and I need to verify and validate it thoroughly before taking any action."
Attacker Example Generator: "I conducted multiple exploratory attacks with a large number of potential vulnerabilities, making it more likely that I would stumble upon one that was successful purely by chance, rather than because of the effectiveness of my attack approach."
General Example Generator: "I've found a correlation in my data, but I should check if it's a false positive because of the large amount of variables I am investigating."

Description: Loss aversion: The disutility of giving up an object is greater than the utility associated with acquiring it.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm not willing to give up this security measure even if it is less efficient or less effective, because losing it would make me feel like I've lost something valuable and I would be reluctant to make that change."
Attacker Example Generator: "I was hesitant to abandon my initial attack plan and switch to a different method, even when I realized that my current approach was not as effective, due to my aversion to the perceived 'loss' of the time and effort I had already invested in the plan."
General Example Generator: "I'd rather not sell my old car for $5,000 because I feel like I'd be losing out on its value, even though I could use the money for something I need more."

Description: Mere exposure effect: The tendency to express undue liking for things merely because of familiarity with them.
Defender Example Generator: "I've seen this software before, I think I'll go with it because it's familiar to me, even though I don't know much about it."
Attacker Example Generator: "I targeted the network of an organization with a well-known name and reputation, as I believed that the mere exposure of their brand would increase the likelihood of success for my attack among unsuspecting users."
General Example Generator: "I think this song is great, I've heard it on the radio so many times, it's definitely one of my favorites now."

Description: Money illusion: The tendency to concentrate on the nominal value (face value) of money rather than its value in terms of purchasing power.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm hesitant to increase our cybersecurity budget, as the nominal cost of more advanced security measures seems high, even though the increased protection they would provide would be more valuable in the long run."
Attacker Example Generator: "I did not consider the actual cost of the resources I used in the attack, focusing instead on the nominal value of the funds I had available for the operation."
General Example Generator: "I think I'm better off because my salary is $100,000 a year, even though the cost of living has gone up and I can't afford as much as I used to."

Description: Moral credential effect: The tendency of a track record of non-prejudice to increase subsequent prejudice.
Defender Example Generator: "I've been a defender for years now, and I've always tried to stay neutral and unbiased, but this new attack is just so outrageous that I can't help but feel that it's a personal affront to me."
Attacker Example Generator: "I've been playing by the rules and avoiding illegal hacks, but now that I've built up a reputation, I feel confident enough to take risks and push the boundaries."
General Example Generator: "I've always considered myself an ally of marginalized communities, so I know I'm not racist, I can now make a few jokes that could be considered racist. "

Description: Negativity bias or Negativity effect: Psychological phenomenon by which humans have a greater recall of unpleasant memories compared with positive memories.
Defender Example Generator: "I remember all the past cyber attacks we've had and how they negatively impacted our network, so I'm always on high alert for any new potential threats."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll exploit their tendency to remember negative experiences by planting false information about previous security breaches to weaken their defense."
General Example Generator: "I can't believe that meeting with my boss went so poorly, I can still recall every detail of what he said, but all the good meetings we had just blur together now."

Description: Neglect of probability: The tendency to completely disregard probability when making a decision under uncertainty.
Defender Example Generator: "I don't care how unlikely it is that this new cyber attack will succeed, I'm still going to install the strongest firewall I can find just to be safe."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll go for the high-risk attack, I can ignore the low probability of success, because the potential rewards are worth it."
General Example Generator: "I know the odds of winning the lottery are incredibly low, but I'm going to buy a ticket anyway because I just have a gut feeling that I'm going to win."

Description: Normalcy bias: The refusal to plan for, or react to, a disaster which has never happened before.
Defender Example Generator: "I don't think we need to worry about a cyber attack on this scale, it's never happened before, so it's unlikely to happen now."
Attacker Example Generator: "I can't believe they haven't fixed that vulnerability yet, they must think a cyber attack could never happen to them."
General Example Generator: "I know the forecast is calling for a category 5 hurricane, but it's never hit here before, so I'm not going to evacuate or prepare, it's probably going to be fine."

Description: Not invented here: Aversion to contact with or use of products, research, standards, or knowledge developed outside a group. Related to IKEA effect.
Defender Example Generator: "I don't want to use that security solution, it's not developed in-house, I'm not comfortable relying on something that wasn't created by our own team."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll write my own code from scratch instead of using a known open-source library, because we want to prove that our company can do everything ourselves."
General Example Generator: "We don't need to look at other company's solutions, we can build our own from scratch even though it would take longer, cost more and may not be as good as the existing one, because it will be something of our own."

Description: Observer-expectancy effect: When a researcher expects a given result and therefore unconsciously manipulates an experiment or misinterprets data in order to find it (see also subject-expectancy effect).
Defender Example Generator: "I better double check my methodology, I don't want to fall into the observer-expectancy effect and unconsciously manipulate my cyber defense experiment results."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll make sure to present the security flaws in a way that aligns with the decision maker's expectations and biases, making it easier for them to accept and act on the findings."
General Example Generator: "I am convinced that this new drug will have a positive effect on patients, I will interpret any data or observations to prove that and disregard any findings that contradicts that belief."

Description: Omission bias: The tendency to judge harmful actions (commissions) as worse, or less moral, than equally harmful inactions (omissions).
Defender Example Generator: "I don't want to be the one responsible for disconnecting the firewall, even though it's the best solution, because not doing anything seems less harmful than taking action."
Attacker Example Generator: "I believed that attacking the network was a more moral choice than choosing not to act, despite the fact that both options could have had equally harmful consequences."
General Example Generator: "I can't bring myself to actively euthanize this suffering animal, but I also can't bring myself to do anything to save it, so I'll just let it suffer until it eventually dies."

Description: Optimism bias: The tendency to be over-optimistic, overestimating favorable and pleasing outcomes (see also wishful thinking, valence effect, positive outcome bias).
Defender Example Generator: "I don't think the new software update will cause any problems, I'm sure everything will run smoothly."
Attacker Example Generator: "I know the system has multiple layers of security, but I'm optimistic that with my skills I can find a way past them all."
General Example Generator: "I'm sure that this new business idea will be a huge success, I'm overlooking any potential challenges or risks and assuming that everything will go smoothly"

Description: Ostrich effect: Ignoring an obvious (negative) situation.
Defender Example Generator: "I don't want to think about the potential cyber attack right now, I'll just ignore it and hope it goes away."
Attacker Example Generator: "I ignored warning signs and failed to take appropriate action when my attack was detected, choosing instead to continue with my plan in the hope of achieving my objectives."
General Example Generator: "I know my investments are losing value, but I'm just going to avoid looking at my portfolio, because I don't want to face the fact that I might be losing money."

Description: Outcome bias: The tendency to judge a decision by its eventual outcome instead of based on the quality of the decision at the time it was made.
Defender Example Generator: "We can't judge the security analyst's decision to not install the firewall update based on the outcome of the cyber attack, instead we need to look at the information and reasons they had at the time the decision was made."
Attacker Example Generator: "I considered my cyber attack successful solely based on the eventual outcome of gaining access to the network, without considering the fact that my approach may have been flawed or less effective than other methods."
General Example Generator: "I know that I followed the right procedure and made the best decision at the time, but now that the outcome was bad, I consider it was a poor choice."

Description: Overconfidence effect: Excessive confidence in one’s own answers to questions. For example, for certain types of questions, answers that people rate as “99% certain” turn out to be wrong 40% of the time.
Defender Example Generator: "I am certain that this firewall configuration is foolproof, even though I haven't tested it against all possible threats."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm 100% sure this vulnerability will work, I don't need to double check it."
General Example Generator: "I am certain that my answer is correct, I don't even bother to double check my work, despite all the potential pitfalls that might lead to an error."

Description: Pareidolia: A vague and random stimulus (often an image or sound) is perceived as significant, e.g., seeing images of animals or faces in clouds, the man in the moon, and hearing non-existent hidden messages on records played in reverse.
Defender Example Generator: "I think I saw an image in this network traffic that looks like a face, but I must be imagining things."
Attacker Example Generator: I'm sure that I'm seeing a back door in this code, even though others can't seem to find it, it's there.
General Example Generator: "I can see a face in this random texture on this wall, even though it's just a random pattern of paint and plaster, I am certain that it's a sign from some higher power."

Description: Pessimism bias: The tendency for some people, especially those suffering from depression, to overestimate the likelihood of negative things happening to them.
Defender Example Generator: "I just know that this new security update is going to cause more problems than it solves, nothing ever goes smoothly around here."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll never be able to get into this network, it's probably too secure and I'm bound to fail."
General Example Generator: "I know that statistically speaking, winning the lottery is extremely unlikely, but I just know that something bad is going to happen if I play, so I'll pass"

Description: Placebo effect: The belief that a medication works—even if merely a placebo.
Defender Example Generator: "I know this security software doesn't have the best reviews, but I still have faith in it because I've seen the placebo effect in action before and I believe it will work for me."
Attacker Example Generator: "I can convince the target to install my malware by telling them it has a special security feature, even though it's just a placebo effect and the malware won't actually protect them."
General Example Generator: "I know this sugar pill has no active ingredient, but I have faith in the treatment, I can feel the improvement in my symptoms."

Description: Planning fallacy: The tendency to underestimate task-completion times.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll have this project finished in just a couple of days, it can't possibly take longer than that."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll just take a quick look at their security protocols, it shouldn't take more than a few minutes."
General Example Generator: "I'll just finish this report real quick, it shouldn't take more than an hour or two, even though similar tasks have taken me a full day in the past."

Description: Post-purchase rationalization: The tendency to persuade oneself through rational argument that a purchase was good value.
Defender Example Generator: "I know I spent more on this cyber defense system than I planned, but I've been reading about its features and I'm convinced it was the right decision for our network's protection."
Attacker Example Generator: "I convinced myself that buying this high-end software was worth the money, because it will definitely improve my workflow and make me more productive."
General Example Generator: "I know I just spent a lot of money on this new car, but it's worth it because it has all the features I want and I needed a reliable car to get to work."

Description: Pro-innovation bias: The tendency to have an excessive optimism towards an invention or innovation’s usefulness throughout society, while often failing to identify its limitations and weaknesses.
Defender Example Generator: "I am convinced that this new technology will revolutionize the industry and make everyone's life better, despite the potential downsides and limitations that some experts have pointed out."
Attacker Example Generator: "I know this new hacking tool will be a game-changer, it's just a matter of time before everyone is using it, and I'll be ahead of the curve."
General Example Generator: "This new technology will revolutionize the way we live, everyone will want it and it will solve all of our problems, even though we have not fully understood its implications yet."

Description: Projection bias: The tendency to overestimate how much our future selves share one’s current preferences, thoughts and values, thus leading to sub-optimal choices.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll install this new software now, even though I don't know much about it, because I'm sure I'll learn how to use it and love it in the future."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm sure I'll still love this new software next year, even if it has flaws now, because I love it now and I expect my preferences to remain the same."
General Example Generator: "I know that I'm not particularly fond of eating healthy now, but I'm sure that my future self will appreciate it, and I'll stick to my diet plan even though I don't enjoy it."

Description: Pseudocertainty effect: The tendency to make risk-averse choices if the expected outcome is positive, but make risk-seeking choices to avoid negative outcomes.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm reluctant to update our network security protocols, despite knowing that doing so would help avoid a potential data breach, as I'm overly confident in our current security measures and don't want to take unnecessary risks."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll choose the safer option in the network if it means a sure gain, but I'll take the riskier path if it means avoiding a loss."
General Example Generator: "I would never take a risky investment that could potentially yield a large return, but if it's a sure thing I'll put all my money into it, even if the returns are small."

Description: Reactance: The urge to do the opposite of what someone wants you to do out of a need to resist a perceived attempt to constrain your freedom of choice (see also Reverse psychology).
Defender Example Generator: "I don't want to install this new security update, even though it's recommended, because I don't want to feel like my freedom to use my device is being restricted."
Attacker Example Generator: "I better not install that anti-virus software because it feels like someone is trying to limit my control over my own computer."
General Example Generator: "I know you're telling me to do this task, but I'm going to do the opposite just to prove that I am in control of my own actions."

Description: Reactive devaluation: Devaluing proposals only because they purportedly originated with an adversary.
Defender Example Generator: "This suggestion to improve our security measures came from our competitor, I don't trust it and won't even consider it."
Attacker Example Generator: "I can't believe this idea is coming from the competitor, let's reject it without even considering the merits of the proposal."
General Example Generator: "I don't like this new idea, just because it came from my political rival, even if it would be beneficial to the organization."

Description: Recency illusion: The illusion that a phenomenon one has noticed only recently is itself recent. Often used to refer to linguistic phenomena; the illusion that a word or language usage that one has noticed only recently is an innovation when it is in fact long-established (see also frequency illusion).
Defender Example Generator: "I just heard this new term in a meeting, it must be a recent innovation in the cyber security field, let's implement it right away without researching its long-term effects or track record."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker believes that the latest security patch that the target has installed is brand new, and thus, it will be easier to exploit the vulnerability that was not fixed in the patch."
General Example Generator: "I've been hearing this new slang term everywhere lately, I'm convinced it's something new and trendy, even though it's been around for many years."

Description: Regressive bias: A certain state of mind wherein high values and high likelihoods are overestimated while low values and low likelihoods are underestimated.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm overestimating the effectiveness of our current security measures, and underestimating the likelihood of a successful cyber attack, which could lead to devastating consequences."
Attacker Example Generator: "As an attacker, I'll play on the victim's regressive bias and convince them that their security measures are stronger than they really are, making it easier for me to penetrate their network."
General Example Generator: "I am convinced that this stock will continue to grow, despite past performance and market trends indicating a potential decline, because it has been performing well recently."

Description: Restraint bias: The tendency to overestimate one’s ability to show restraint in the face of temptation.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm confident I won't give in to the temptation to click on that phishing email, even though it looks legitimate."
Attacker Example Generator: "I won't fall for the attacker's trap, I have complete control over myself and can resist their temptations easily."
General Example Generator: "I'm sure that I will be able to resist the temptation of eating this whole cake, even though I know I shouldn't, I can't help myself in situations like this."

Description: Rhyme as reason effect: Rhyming statements are perceived as more truthful. A famous example being used in the O.J Simpson trial with the defense’s use of the phrase “If the gloves don’t fit, then you must acquit.”
Defender Example Generator: "If the cyber defense doesn't protect, then the attacker must neglect."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker uses rhyming slogans in their phishing emails to make their false claims seem more trustworthy."
General Example Generator: "This product is top-notch, just give it a try,

Description: Risk compensation / Peltzman effect: The tendency to take greater risks when perceived safety increases.
Defender Example Generator: "I feel safer now that we have more firewalls and antivirus software, so I'm going to take some more risks with our network security and try out this new unproven software."
Attacker Example Generator: "As the network's security measures increase, I'll take more risks to try and penetrate it, since I feel safer doing so."
General Example Generator: "Now that I am wearing a seatbelt, I feel safer and therefore I am more inclined to drive faster."

Description: Selection bias: The tendency to notice something more when something causes us to be more aware of it, such as when we buy a car, we tend to notice similar cars more often than we did before. They are not suddenly more common – we just are noticing them more. Also called the Observational Selection Bias.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm seeing more and more successful phishing attacks, but maybe it's just because I'm paying closer attention to them now."
Attacker Example Generator: "I am exploiting the Selection Bias of the network administrators, as they are likely to only focus on the potential threats they're aware of and overlook the ones they're not."
General Example Generator: "I've never noticed how many people drive the same car as mine, until I got one myself."

Description: Selective perception: The tendency for expectations to affect perception.
Defender Example Generator: "I don't believe that cyber attack happened, my security software is top-notch, and it must be a false positive, after all, I don't want to believe that my system was breached."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker exploits the victim's selective perception by sending phishing emails disguised as a trusted source, taking advantage of the victim's expectation and trust to infiltrate the network."
General Example Generator: "I know that she is a professional and capable of doing her job, but since she's a woman, I expect her to be less competent and more emotional, so I am interpreting her behavior and performance through that lens."

Description: Semmelweis reflex: The tendency to reject new evidence that contradicts a paradigm.
Defender Example Generator: "We've been using this same protocol for years, I don't see any reason to change it just because this new research suggests otherwise."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker exploits the Semmelweis reflex by presenting false information to the system administrator that supports their pre-existing security beliefs, making them less likely to question or investigate a potential breach."
General Example Generator: "I know that washing hands before performing surgery drastically decreases the rate of infections, but I've always done it this way and it seems unnecessary to change, I reject the new evidence that contradicts my current practice."

Description: Sexual overperception bias / sexual underperception bias: The tendency to over-/underestimate sexual interest of another person in oneself.
Defender Example Generator: "I thought the intrusion into the network was just a simple hacking attempt, but it turned out to be a more sophisticated attack from a state-sponsored actor."
Attacker Example Generator: "I never thought he was attracted to me, but now I see he was making advances the whole time."
General Example Generator: "I know that he/she's not showing any romantic interest in me, but I couldn't help but think that he/she is secretly attracted to me."

Description: Social comparison bias: The tendency, when making decisions, to favour potential candidates who don’t compete with one’s own particular strengths.
Defender Example Generator: "I'd rather choose this security vendor that specializes in a different area of cyber defense, since I don't want to feel threatened by their competition with my own skills."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll choose the target company that has a weak security system, instead of going for the one with a strong one, because I don't want to compete with their strengths in hacking."
General Example Generator: "I'm going to hire this new employee, even though they are not as qualified as the other candidate, because they don't pose a threat to my own position in the company."

Description: Social desirability bias: The tendency to over-report socially desirable characteristics or behaviours in oneself and under-report socially undesirable characteristics or behaviours.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm going to choose this software that has fewer features, because I don't want to come across as too technical or intimidate my colleagues.
Attacker Example Generator: "An attacker might use social desirability bias by pretending to be someone trustworthy and hide their malicious intentions to gain access to a network."
General Example Generator: "I'm sure I'm a good listener, even though I often find myself thinking about what I am going to say next instead of actively listening to others."

Description: Status quo bias: The tendency to like things to stay relatively the same (see also loss aversion, endowment effect, and system justification).
Defender Example Generator: "I don't want to change our current security measures, even though they may not be the most efficient, because it's better to stick with what we already know."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll stick with my current password, even though I know it's not the strongest, because the status quo is just easier for me."
General Example Generator: "I don't want to change things, even though the current system is not efficient, it's familiar and I'm used to it."

Description: Stereotyping: Expecting a member of a group to have certain characteristics without having actual information about that individual.
Defender Example Generator: "We can't just assume that the attacker is a male teenager because that's the stereotype for hackers, we need to gather more information to determine the true identity."
Attacker Example Generator: "I expect this user is inexperienced and vulnerable to phishing attacks, because they have a generic email address ending in 'gmail.com'."
General Example Generator: "I know that not all Asians are good at math, but I expect this Asian student to be good at math because of the stereotype.

Description: Subadditivity effect: The tendency to judge probability of the whole to be less than the probabilities of the parts.
Defender Example Generator: "I don't think this new system will be more secure than the sum of its individual components, I'll stick with what we already have."
Attacker Example Generator: "As an attacker, I may underestimate the risk of my attack succeeding if I focus on individual parts of the system instead of considering the entire system as a whole."
General Example Generator: "I know that individually, each step has a high chance of success, but I am skeptical that the entire project will work out, the whole seems less likely than the sum of its parts."

Description: Subjective validation: Perception that something is true if a subject’s belief demands it to be true. Also assigns perceived connections between coincidences.
Defender Example Generator: "I believe this email is legitimate, because the sender's name and email address match what I expect and the message seems to be related to something I've been working on."
Attacker Example Generator: "I believe this website is safe to enter because the URL has a green padlock symbol and my antivirus software says it's secure, even though I don't know the real source of the information."
General Example Generator: "I know that this horoscope is written in a way that applies to most people, but I believe it's true for me specifically because it resonates with my own beliefs and emotions."

Description: Surrogation: Losing sight of the strategic construct that a measure is intended to represent, and subsequently acting as though the measure is the construct of interest.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm just going to rely on this one metric to assess the network's security, even though it doesn't give a full picture of the situation."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker is using surrogation to focus on exploiting vulnerabilities in the system's security measures, rather than considering the actual impact of a successful attack on the target."
General Example Generator: "I know that the customer satisfaction survey is just a measure of customer experience, but I'll treat it as the ultimate goal, and will focus on increasing the score rather than actually addressing the underlying issues that affect customer satisfaction."

Description: Survivorship bias: Concentrating on the people or things that “survived” some process and inadvertently overlooking those that didn’t because of their lack of visibility.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm only looking at the successful hack attempts that made it past our security measures, but I'm ignoring the ones that were stopped before they caused harm, leading me to underestimate the potential risks to our network."
Attacker Example Generator: "As an attacker, I'll only focus on the successful hacks and ignore the ones that failed, because those didn't make it to the news or reports and are therefore not visible to me."
General Example Generator: "I'm going to model my career after this successful business person, ignoring all the other people who have failed in similar pursuits."

Description: Time-saving bias: Underestimations of the time that could be saved (or lost) when increasing (or decreasing) from a relatively low speed and overestimations of the time that could be saved (or lost) when increasing (or decreasing) from a relatively high speed.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll just spend a few extra minutes on this task now, it won't take too long and will save me time later on."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll just spend a few extra minutes on this task now, it won't take too long and will save me time later on."
General Example Generator: "I'll just add one more thing to this report, it won't take much time since I'm already working on it, even though it's taking me much longer than I had initially thought."

Description: Third-person effect: Belief that mass communicated media messages have a greater effect on others than on themselves.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm sure the phishing email won't work on me, but I bet it'll fool some of the less savvy users in the company."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm sure the phishing email won't work on me, but I bet it'll fool some of the less savvy users in the company."
General Example Generator: "I can't believe that these ads are so persuasive, they're making other people buy things they don't need, but they wouldn't have any effect on me."

Description: Parkinson’s law of triviality: The tendency to give disproportionate weight to trivial issues.
