Also known as bikeshedding, this bias explains why an organization may avoid specialized or complex subjects, such as the design of a nuclear reactor, and instead focus on something easy to grasp or rewarding to the average participant, such as the design of an adjacent bike shed.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll focus on the design of the bike shed instead of the nuclear reactor, it's a trivial issue that everyone can understand and feel good about contributing to."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll focus on the design of the bike shed instead of the nuclear reactor, it's a trivial issue that everyone can understand and feel good about contributing to."
General Example Generator: "I know that this meeting is supposed to be about the company's long-term strategic plan, but we are spending hours discussing the color of the walls in the kitchen, a trivial matter."

Description: Unit bias: The standard suggested amount of consumption (e.g., food serving size) is perceived to be appropriate, and a person would consume it all even if it is too much for this particular person.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll eat the whole serving of food, even though it's too much for me, because the suggested serving size seems like the right amount."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll eat the whole serving of food, even though it's too much for me, because the suggested serving size seems like the right amount."
General Example Generator: "I know that I am already full, but since the serving size is enough for 2 people, I will finish everything on my plate."

Description: Weber–Fechner law: Difficulty in comparing small differences in large quantities.
Defender Example Generator: "An attacker might exploit the Weber-Fechner law by disguising small changes in large amounts of code to avoid detection by the target's security team."
Attacker Example Generator: "An attacker might exploit the Weber-Fechner law by disguising small changes in large amounts of code to avoid detection by the target's security team."
General Example Generator: "I know that the price difference between these two products is small, but it seems much more significant because the prices are so high."

Description: Well travelled road effect: Underestimation of the duration taken to traverse oft-traveled routes and overestimation of the duration taken to traverse less familiar routes.
Defender Example Generator: "I always underestimate how long it will take me to get home from work, but I always overestimate how long it will take me to get to a new place."
Attacker Example Generator: "I always underestimate how long it will take me to get home from work, but I always overestimate how long it will take me to get to a new place."
General Example Generator: "I know that it usually takes me 20 minutes to get to work by car, but this new route is taking much longer than I expected, it's probably because I'm not as familiar with it."

Description: Women are wonderful effect: A tendency to associate more positive attributes with women than with men.
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker assumes that the female IT staff member is more likely to fall for social engineering tactics because they believe women are more trusting and naive."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker assumes that the female IT staff member is more likely to fall for social engineering tactics because they believe women are more trusting and naive."
General Example Generator: "I know that both candidates are equally qualified for this job but I am more inclined to hire the female candidate, I assume that she will be more nurturing and better at multitasking."

Description: Zero-risk bias: Preference for reducing a small risk to zero over a greater reduction in a larger risk.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll only target small companies with weak security measures, even though they might not have valuable data, because the risk of getting caught is zero, unlike going after a big corporation with better security."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll only target small companies with weak security measures, even though they might not have valuable data, because the risk of getting caught is zero, unlike going after a big corporation with better security."
General Example Generator: "I am going to invest all my money in a government bond that has a low return, even though there are other investments that would yield a higher return, I know that they're also riskier but I want to reduce the risk to zero."

Description: Zero-sum bias: A bias whereby a situation is incorrectly perceived to be like a zero-sum game (i.e., one person gains at the expense of another).
Defender Example Generator: The attacker sees the network's security measures as a zero-sum game, where any advantage they gain must come at the expense of the network's defenses.
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker sees the network's security measures as a zero-sum game, where any advantage they gain must come at the expense of the network's defenses."
General Example Generator: "I know that this situation isn't a zero-sum game, but I am acting as if it is, assuming that if my colleague succeeds, it will come at the expense of my own success."

Description: Actor-observer bias: The tendency for explanations of other individuals’ behaviors to overemphasize the influence of their personality and underemphasize the influence of their situation (see also Fundamental attribution error), and for explanations of one’s own behaviors to do the opposite (that is, to overemphasize the influence of our situation and underemphasize the influence of our own personality).
Defender Example Generator: "I'm blaming the victim's poor security measures, not my skills, for my successful hacking attempt into their system."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm blaming the victim's poor security measures, not my skills, for my successful hacking attempt into their system."
General Example Generator: "He's late again, he must be irresponsible, while I am late because of the traffic."

Description: Authority bias: The tendency to attribute greater accuracy to the opinion of an authority figure (unrelated to its content) and be more influenced by that opinion.
Defender Example Generator: The network administrator is a well-respected authority in the field, so I'll take their word for it and not bother double-checking their security measures."
Attacker Example Generator: "The network administrator is a well-respected authority in the field, so I'll take their word for it and not bother double-checking their security measures."
General Example Generator: "I know that this person's opinion is not necessarily any more valid than mine, but since they have a certain title or position, I will trust their judgement more and follow their advice."

Description: Cheerleader effect: The tendency for people to appear more attractive in a group than in isolation.
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker might use the cheerleader effect by convincing the target that they are part of a group that supports the attacker's scam or attack, thus appearing more trustworthy and attractive to the target."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker might use the cheerleader effect by convincing the target that they are part of a group that supports the attacker's scam or attack, thus appearing more trustworthy and attractive to the target."
General Example Generator: "I know that she's not necessarily good looking, but when she's hanging out with her attractive friends, she seems to be more attractive"

Description: Defensive attribution hypothesis: Attributing more blame to a harm-doer as the outcome becomes more severe or as personal or situational similarity to the victim increases.
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker is blaming the victim for not having proper security measures in place, claiming that they brought the attack on themselves, as they seem to have similar vulnerabilities as the attacker's previous targets."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker is blaming the victim for not having proper security measures in place, claiming that they brought the attack on themselves, as they seem to have similar vulnerabilities as the attacker's previous targets."
General Example Generator: "I know that the accident was caused by a system failure, but I'm going to blame the operator for it, the severity of the accident make me assign more blame to the operator."

Description: Egocentric bias: Occurs when people claim more responsibility for themselves for the results of a joint action than an outside observer would credit them with.
Defender Example Generator: "I hacked into this system all by myself, I deserve all the credit for this successful breach, even though it was a team effort."
Attacker Example Generator: "I hacked into this system all by myself, I deserve all the credit for this successful breach, even though it was a team effort."
General Example Generator: "I know that we all worked together to make this project successful, but I am going to take most of the credit for it, since I believe that my contribution was the most important."

Description: Extrinsic incentives bias: An exception to the fundamental attribution error, when people view others as having (situational) extrinsic motivations and (dispositional) intrinsic motivations for oneself
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker takes advantage of the extrinsic incentives bias by convincing the target that they are motivated by external rewards to divulge sensitive information, while they themselves are motivated by internal values to keep it secure."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker takes advantage of the extrinsic incentives bias by convincing the target that they are motivated by external rewards to divulge sensitive information, while they themselves are motivated by internal values to keep it secure."
General Example Generator: "I know that I am working for the money, but I assume that the others are working for the love of the job."

Description: False consensus effect: The tendency for people to overestimate the degree to which others agree with them.
Defender Example Generator: "I am sure everyone else on this network would love to have this information, I just know it, because I'm sure they all think like me."
Attacker Example Generator: "I am sure everyone else on this network would love to have this information, I just know it, because I'm sure they all think like me."
General Example Generator: "I know that this is just my opinion and not everyone thinks the same, but I believe that most people agree with me."

Description: Forer effect (aka Barnum effect): The tendency to give high accuracy ratings to descriptions of their personality that supposedly are tailored specifically for them, but are in fact vague and general enough to apply to a wide range of people. For example, horoscopes.
Defender Example Generator: "I can trick this person into believing my fake horoscope reading because they'll attribute high accuracy to the vague, general description due to the Forer effect."
Attacker Example Generator: "I can trick this person into believing my fake horoscope reading because they'll attribute high accuracy to the vague, general description due to the Forer effect."
General Example Generator: "I know that this horoscope is written in a way that applies to most people, but I believe it's specifically true for me."

Description: Fundamental attribution error: The tendency for people to over-emphasize personality-based explanations for behaviors observed in others while under-emphasizing the role and power of situational influences on the same behavior
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker assumes the target's security choices are a result of their personality, ignoring the situational factors that might have led to those choices."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker assumes the target's security choices are a result of their personality, ignoring the situational factors that might have led to those choices."
General Example Generator: "I know that the reason he's acting this way is because of the difficult situation he's going through, but I'm going to assume that it's because of his personality."

Description: Group attribution error: The biased belief that the characteristics of an individual group member are reflective of the group as a whole or the tendency to assume that group decision outcomes reflect the preferences of group members, even when information is available that clearly suggests otherwise.
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker takes advantage of the group attribution error by assuming that a specific weakness in one employee's security measures is representative of the entire company's security, leading to a successful attack."
Attacker Example Generator: "I attributed the security vulnerabilities of the entire organization to the perceived lack of technical knowledge of one employee, without considering the possibility that other factors might be at play."
General Example Generator: "I know that the group has different opinions, but I'm going to assume that we all think the same way"

Description: Halo effect: The tendency for a person’s positive or negative traits to “spill over” from one personality area to another in others’ perceptions of them (see also physical attractiveness stereotype).
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker manipulates the target's perception of their trustworthiness by creating a positive image, making them more susceptible to follow their commands."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker manipulates the target's perception of their trustworthiness by creating a positive image, making them more susceptible to follow their commands."
General Example Generator: "I know that this person might not be good at this task, but since they excel in other areas, I am going to assume they are good at this too."

Description: Illusion of asymmetric insight: People perceive their knowledge of their peers to surpass their peers’ knowledge of them.
Defender Example Generator: "I know everything about my target's network, but they have no idea what I know about them."
Attacker Example Generator: "I know everything about my target's network, but they have no idea what I know about them."
General Example Generator: "I know that I have a lot of information about this person, but I don't think they know that much about me."

Description: Illusion of external agency: When people view self-generated preferences as instead being caused by insightful, effective and benevolent agents.
Defender Example Generator: "I think my target chose this password because it was recommended by a supposed security expert, but really I just planted the idea in their mind through social engineering."
Attacker Example Generator: "I think my target chose this password because it was recommended by a supposed security expert, but really I just planted the idea in their mind through social engineering."
General Example Generator: "I know that this was my idea, but I am going to say that I got it from a book, a website or a friend, so it seems more valuable."

Description: Illusion of transparency: People overestimate others’ ability to know them, and they also overestimate their ability to know others.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm sure they don't know my intentions and motivations, they'll never suspect me even though I'm manipulating them into believing I'm on their side."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm sure they don't know my intentions and motivations, they'll never suspect me even though I'm manipulating them into believing I'm on their side."
General Example Generator: "I know that I am not that good at hiding my feelings, but I believe that nobody knows what I'm thinking."

Description: Illusory superiority: Overestimating one’s desirable qualities, and underestimating undesirable qualities, relative to other people. (Also known as “Lake Wobegon effect”, “better-than-average effect”, or “superiority bias“.)
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker overestimates their own hacking skills and underestimates their victims' security measures due to the illusory superiority bias."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker overestimates their own hacking skills and underestimates their victims' security measures due to the illusory superiority bias."
General Example Generator: "I know that I am not better than the average person in this skill, but I am going to rate myself as above average."

Description: Ingroup bias: The tendency for people to give preferential treatment to others they perceive to be members of their own groups.
Defender Example Generator: "An attacker exploits the ingroup bias by posing as a member of a group the target identifies with, thus gaining their trust and cooperation."
Attacker Example Generator: "An attacker exploits the ingroup bias by posing as a member of a group the target identifies with, thus gaining their trust and cooperation."
General Example Generator: "I know that this person is not more qualified for this task, but since they are part of my group, I am going to choose them."

Description: Just-world hypothesis: The tendency for people to want to believe that the world is fundamentally just, causing them to rationalize an otherwise inexplicable injustice as deserved by the victim(s).
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker exploits the victims' belief in the just-world hypothesis by making them believe that the negative consequences they are facing are a result of their own actions, rather than the attacker's malicious intentions."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker exploits the victims' belief in the just-world hypothesis by making them believe that the negative consequences they are facing are a result of their own actions, rather than the attacker's malicious intentions."
General Example Generator: "I know that this person has gone through a lot of suffering, but I am going to believe that they deserved it."

Description: Moral luck: The tendency for people to ascribe greater or lesser moral standing based on the outcome of an event.
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker takes advantage of the victim's tendency to ascribe greater or lesser moral standing based on the outcome of a cyber attack, manipulating the perception of the incident to minimize their own responsibility."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker takes advantage of the victim's tendency to ascribe greater or lesser moral standing based on the outcome of a cyber attack, manipulating the perception of the incident to minimize their own responsibility."
General Example Generator: "I know that this person made the same decision as I did, but since their outcome was better, I am going to say that they made the right decision."

Description: Naïve cynicism: Expecting more egocentric bias in others than in oneself.
Defender Example Generator: "An attacker takes advantage of a victim's assumption that they are more aware of bias in others than themselves by using egocentric behavior to manipulate them."
Attacker Example Generator: "An attacker takes advantage of a victim's assumption that they are more aware of bias in others than themselves by using egocentric behavior to manipulate them."
General Example Generator: "I know that I have my own biases, but I am going to assume that others are more influenced by them."

Description: Naïve realism: The belief that we see reality as it really is – objectively and without bias; that the facts are plain for all to see; that rational people will agree with us; and that those who don’t are either uninformed, lazy, irrational, or biased.
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker exploits the naive realism of the target by presenting false information as the objective truth, leading the target to make decisions based on misinformation."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker exploits the naive realism of the target by presenting false information as the objective truth, leading the target to make decisions based on misinformation."
General Example Generator: "I know that my perception of this event may be influenced by my own biases, but I am going to believe that my perception is the only right one."

Description: Outgroup homogeneity bias: Individuals see members of their own group as being relatively more varied than members of other groups.
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker uses the outgroup homogeneity bias to exploit the belief of the target that members of the attacker's group are all similar, leading the target to underestimate the range of potential threats."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker uses the outgroup homogeneity bias to exploit the belief of the target that members of the attacker's group are all similar, leading the target to underestimate the range of potential threats."
General Example Generator: "I know that there are many different types of people in the group I am not a part of, but I am going to assume that they are all similar to each other."

Description: Self-serving bias: The tendency to claim more responsibility for successes than failures. It may also manifest itself as a tendency for people to evaluate ambiguous information in a way beneficial to their interests (see also group-serving bias).
Defender Example Generator: "A cyber attacker may exploit the self-serving bias by making victims believe that the security breach was their own fault, rather than the attacker's actions."
Attacker Example Generator: "A cyber attacker may exploit the self-serving bias by making victims believe that the security breach was their own fault, rather than the attacker's actions."
General Example Generator: "I know that I played a small part in this success, but I am going to take credit for it as if it were entirely because of me."

Description: Shared information bias: Known as the tendency for group members to spend more time and energy discussing information that all members are already familiar with (i.e., shared information), and less time and energy discussing information that only some members are aware of (i.e., unshared information).
Defender Example Generator: "An attacker can use the shared information bias to manipulate a group into only considering information that supports their objectives, while downplaying information that may challenge or contradict those objectives."
Attacker Example Generator: "An attacker can use the shared information bias to manipulate a group into only considering information that supports their objectives, while downplaying information that may challenge or contradict those objectives."
General Example Generator: "We've been discussing the budget for the project for an hour now, but we haven't even touched on the new market research that John presented."

Description: System justification: The tendency to defend and bolster the status quo. Existing social, economic, and political arrangements tend to be preferred, and alternatives disparaged, sometimes even at the expense of individual and collective self-interest. (See also status quo bias.)
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker takes advantage of the system justification bias by presenting their malicious intentions as being in line with the status quo, to gain the trust and cooperation of their target."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker takes advantage of the system justification bias by presenting their malicious intentions as being in line with the status quo, to gain the trust and cooperation of their target."
General Example Generator: I can't believe the company wants to change the way we've been doing things for years, it just makes me want to defend the status quo even more.

Description: Trait ascription bias: The tendency for people to view themselves as relatively variable in terms of personality, behavior, and mood while viewing others as much more predictable.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll target this network administrator because they seem like the type of person who wouldn't expect an attack and wouldn't have strong security measures in place, they're just too predictable."
Attacker Example Generator: "An attacker might use the Trait ascription bias by assuming their target is predictable and manipulable based on their perceived personality traits, while seeing themselves as more adaptable and capable of changing tactics."
General Example Generator: "She always thought that her moods were changeable and different depending on the day, but she always saw her best friend as having a consistent personality."

Description: Ultimate attribution error: Similar to the fundamental attribution error, in this error a person is likely to make an internal attribution to an entire group instead of the individuals within the group.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm going to target this company because they're an entire group of incompetent people who are bound to have weak security measures."
Attacker Example Generator: "An attacker might use the ultimate attribution error by painting a negative image of an entire group to push the target towards a desired outcome, instead of analyzing the actions of the individuals within the group."
General Example Generator: Bob is blaming all the Muslims in the country for the terrorist attacks, and not considering that it's just a small group of extremists.

Description: Worse-than-average effect: A tendency to believe ourselves to be worse than others at tasks which are difficult.
Defender Example Generator: "I think this network is too complicated for me to penetrate, I bet even the best hackers would have trouble with it."
Attacker Example Generator: "I avoided attempting to hack into a more challenging network, assuming that I would be less skilled at it than my peers and that my chances of success would be lower."
General Example Generator: I convinced myself that I am terrible at math, even though I have never taken a math class in my life.

Description: Bizarreness effect: Bizarre material is better remembered than common material.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll make sure to use strange, unusual language in my phishing email, it's more likely to be remembered by the target."
Attacker Example Generator: "I used a particularly unusual form of attack that deviated from the norm, knowing that the bizarre nature of the attack would make it more memorable and increase the likelihood that it would be successful in future attempts."
General Example Generator: "I remembered the giant chicken costume worn by the parade participant, but not the color of the floats"

Description: Choice-supportive bias: In a self-justifying manner retroactively ascribing one’s choices to be more informed than they were when they were made.
Defender Example Generator: "I remember choosing this password because it seemed strong at the time, and I still believe it is the best choice."
Attacker Example Generator: "I convinced myself that my decision to target this particular network was the best one, despite the fact that I had limited information at the time and my choice was based more on intuition than actual facts."
General Example Generator: "I can't believe I used to think that other phone brand was better, now that I've had my new one for a while I realize how much more advanced it is and I made the right choice."

Description: Change bias: After an investment of effort in producing change, remembering one’s past performance as more difficult than it actually was.
Defender Example Generator: I must have chosen the right target, because I've spent so much time researching it and gathering information about it.
Attacker Example Generator: "I must have chosen the right target, because I've spent so much time researching it and gathering information about it."
General Example Generator: "I can't believe how much harder it was to quit smoking back when I first started, it feels like it was so much more difficult than it actually was, I must have put in so much more effort than I remembered"

Description: Childhood amnesia: The retention of few memories from before the age of four.
Defender Example Generator: "I remember the password being easier to crack than it actually was, it must have taken less time and effort."
Attacker Example Generator: "I remember the password being easier to crack than it actually was, it must have taken less time and effort."
General Example Generator: "I can hardly remember anything from before the age of four, it's like it's all a blur."

Description: Conservatism or Regressive bias: Tendency to remember high values and high likelihoods/probabilities/frequencies as lower than they actually were and low ones as higher than they actually were. Based on the evidence, memories are not extreme enough.
Defender Example Generator: "I hacked into this network using the same tactics I always use, it just seems harder now because I don't remember much from when I started."
Attacker Example Generator: "I hacked into this network using the same tactics I always use, it just seems harder now because I don't remember much from when I started."
General Example Generator: "I'm sure I got at least 85% on that test, but when I got my graded paper it was a 78%."

Description: Consistency bias: Incorrectly remembering one’s past attitudes and behaviour as resembling present attitudes and behaviour.
Defender Example Generator: "I've tried many methods to hack this network, but I can't remember which ones worked. I'm going to keep trying different techniques and see what happens, even if it seems like I've already tried it before."
Attacker Example Generator: "I've tried many methods to hack this network, but I can't remember which ones worked. I'm going to keep trying different techniques and see what happens, even if it seems like I've already tried it before."
General Example Generator: "I always knew deep down that I was an early riser, even when I used to sleep in until noon in my college days, but now that I wake up early every day, it makes sense"

Description: Context effect: That cognition and memory are dependent on context, such that out-of-context memories are more difficult to retrieve than in-context memories (e.g., recall time and accuracy for a work-related memory will be lower at home, and vice versa).
Defender Example Generator: "I'm going to claim that I always knew this vulnerability was present in the target system, even though I never mentioned it before, because it aligns with my current stance on security."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm going to claim that I always knew this vulnerability was present in the target system, even though I never mentioned it before, because it aligns with my current stance on security."
General Example Generator: "I can't remember what I said at the meeting last week, but when I got back to my office and saw the notes on my desk, it all came back to me."

Description: Cross-race effect: The tendency for people of one race to have difficulty identifying members of a race other than their own.
Defender Example Generator: "This target is in the perfect mindset, I'll remind them of the previous time they were hacked and exploit their consistency bias by making them believe they were always vulnerable to such attacks."
Attacker Example Generator: "This target is in the perfect mindset, I'll remind them of the previous time they were hacked and exploit their consistency bias by making them believe they were always vulnerable to such attacks."
General Example Generator: "I could not recognize the faces of the people of the different race in the crowd"

Description: Cryptomnesia: A form of misattribution where a memory is mistaken for imagination, because there is no subjective experience of it being a memory.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll use the cross-race effect to my advantage and disguise myself as a system administrator of a different race to gain the target's trust."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll use the cross-race effect to my advantage and disguise myself as a system administrator of a different race to gain the target's trust."
General Example Generator: I had no idea where that idea came from, but later realized I must have read it in a book years ago

Description: Egocentric bias: Recalling the past in a self-serving manner, e.g., remembering one’s exam grades as being better than they were, or remembering a caught fish as bigger than it really was.
Defender Example Generator: "Oh wait, I think I've seen this vulnerability before, but I can't quite remember where... maybe it's just my imagination playing tricks on me."
Attacker Example Generator: "Oh wait, I think I've seen this vulnerability before, but I can't quite remember where... maybe it's just my imagination playing tricks on me."
General Example Generator: "I swear I got an A on that test, not a B+"

Description: Fading affect bias: A bias in which the emotion associated with unpleasant memories fades more quickly than the emotion associated with positive events.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll try to exploit this network again, I'm sure my previous attempts were successful, I just don't remember it that way."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll try to exploit this network again, I'm sure my previous attempts were successful, I just don't remember it that way."
General Example Generator: "I can hardly remember how upset I was when I failed that test, but I can still feel the excitement of getting an A on my last one."

Description: False memory: A form of misattribution where imagination is mistaken for a memory.
Defender Example Generator: "I just convinced the target that the malware I planted is actually just a software update, and they'll believe it even if they realize it's causing harm, because the positive feelings about the update will have faded more quickly than the negative feelings about being attacked."
Attacker Example Generator: "I just convinced the target that the malware I planted is actually just a software update, and they'll believe it even if they realize it's causing harm, because the positive feelings about the update will have faded more quickly than the negative feelings about being attacked."
General Example Generator: "I'm positive that I was at the party last night, but my friends say I wasn't and now I'm starting to doubt my own memory"

Description: Generation effect (Self-generation effect): That self-generated information is remembered best. For instance, people are better able to recall memories of statements that they have generated than similar statements generated by others.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm sure I saw the firewall's vulnerability on a website or a report before, but I can't seem to find it now, maybe it was just my imagination."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm sure I saw the firewall's vulnerability on a website or a report before, but I can't seem to find it now, maybe it was just my imagination."
General Example Generator: "I can't believe I got that question wrong, I'm sure I studied it myself last night, not just reading someone else's notes."

Description: Google effect: The tendency to forget information that can be found readily online by using Internet search engines.
Defender Example Generator: "I don't need to remember the password, I can always Google it."
Attacker Example Generator: "I don't need to remember any technical details of the attack, as I can simply look up any necessary information online whenever I need it."
General Example Generator: I can't seem to recall the name of the actor, but I know I saw him recently in a movie, I'll just Google it.

Description: Hindsight bias: The inclination to see past events as being more predictable than they actually were; also called the “I-knew-it-all-along” effect.
Defender Example Generator: "I knew the target's firewall was weak, I could tell from the first time I tried to penetrate it, now that I succeeded I can say I knew it all along."
Attacker Example Generator: "I successfully infiltrated the network and now it seems obvious that their security was inadequate, even though I had previously thought it would be a more difficult target."
General Example Generator: "I knew that stock was going to tank, I can't believe I didn't sell it sooner."

Description: Humor effect: That humorous items are more easily remembered than non-humorous ones, which might be explained by the distinctiveness of humor, the increased cognitive processing time to understand the humor, or the emotional arousal caused by the humor.
Defender Example Generator: "The security analyst thinks they should have known the attack was coming because it seems so obvious in retrospect, but they didn't flag it before it happened."
Attacker Example Generator: "The security analyst thinks they should have known the attack was coming because it seems so obvious in retrospect, but they didn't flag it before it happened."
General Example Generator: "I can always remember the punchline to that silly joke, but I can't remember where I left my keys."

Description: Illusion of truth effect: That people are more likely to identify as true statements those they have previously heard (even if they cannot consciously remember having heard them), regardless of the actual validity of the statement. In other words, a person is more likely to believe a familiar statement than an unfamiliar one.
Defender Example Generator: "This virus attack is so funny, I bet it'll stick in people's minds better than a boring, straightforward attack."
Attacker Example Generator: "This virus attack is so funny, I bet it'll stick in people's minds better than a boring, straightforward attack."
General Example Generator: "John's statement, which I've heard multiple times, that the earth is flat must be true because it's easy to remember and understand".

Description: Illusory correlation: Inaccurately remembering a relationship between two events.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll use this familiar-looking fake login page to trick the user because they're more likely to believe it's true due to the illusion of truth effect."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll use this familiar-looking fake login page to trick the user because they're more likely to believe it's true due to the illusion of truth effect."
General Example Generator: "I remember that time when I wore that certain shirt and something good happened, so I must wear that shirt whenever I want good things to happen."

Description: Lag effect: The phenomenon whereby learning is greater when studying is spread out over time, as opposed to studying the same amount of time in a single session. See also spacing effect.
Defender Example Generator: "Oh, that phishing email must be legitimate because I've received it several times now, and I remember seeing it before."
Attacker Example Generator: "Oh, that phishing email must be legitimate because I've received it several times now, and I remember seeing it before."
General Example Generator: "I always procrastinate studying for my exams but when I spread it out over a few days before, I always end up getting better grades."

Description: Leveling and sharpening: Memory distortions introduced by the loss of details in a recollection over time, often concurrent with sharpening or selective recollection of certain details that take on exaggerated significance in relation to the details or aspects of the experience lost through leveling. Both biases may be reinforced over time, and by repeated recollection or re-telling of a memory.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll wait to launch this phishing email campaign a few days later so they'll forget about the last one and be more susceptible to falling for it."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll wait to launch this phishing email campaign a few days later so they'll forget about the last one and be more susceptible to falling for it."
General Example Generator: "I remember the dress my friend wore on her wedding day being more detailed and intricate in my memory, but now that I think about it, the details have become blurry and the dress seems simpler than I originally remembered it."

Description: Levels-of-processing effect: That different methods of encoding information into memory have different levels of effectiveness.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll wait to launch the attack until they've forgotten about the last security update, so that their memory of the difficulty of their previous performance is less accurate and easier to exploit."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll wait to launch the attack until they've forgotten about the last security update, so that their memory of the difficulty of their previous performance is less accurate and easier to exploit."
General Example Generator: "I remember the phone number better when I practice saying it aloud, instead of just reading it silently to myself."

Description: List-length effect: A smaller percentage of items are remembered in a longer list, but as the length of the list increases, the absolute number of items remembered increases as well. For example, consider a list of 30 items (“L30”) and a list of 100 items (“L100”). An individual may remember 15 items from L30, or 50%, whereas the individual may remember 40 items from L100, or 40%. Although the percent of L30 items remembered (50%) is greater than the percent of L100 (40%), more L100 items (40) are remembered than L30 items (15).
Defender Example Generator: "I'll make sure to embed the fake update into the system at a deeper level, that way it'll be more memorable and difficult to detect."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll make sure to embed the fake update into the system at a deeper level, that way it'll be more memorable and difficult to detect."
General Example Generator: "Even though I only remembered 40% of the 100 items on the list, that's still 40 items, compared to only remembering 50% of the 30 items on the shorter list, which is only 15 items."

Description: Misinformation effect: Memory becoming less accurate because of interference from post-event information.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll target the users with the shorter password lists first, as they'll be less likely to remember all of them and more susceptible to password reuse."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll target the users with the shorter password lists first, as they'll be less likely to remember all of them and more susceptible to password reuse."
General Example Generator: "I'm sure the thief was wearing a red shirt because that's what the eyewitness on the news said, not the blue shirt I saw them wearing during the robbery."

Description: Modality effect: That memory recall is higher for the last items of a list when the list items were received via speech than when they were received through writing.
Defender Example Generator: "By spreading false rumors about the security measures in place, I can manipulate the target's memory and make them more vulnerable to a cyber attack."
Attacker Example Generator: "By spreading false rumors about the security measures in place, I can manipulate the target's memory and make them more vulnerable to a cyber attack."
General Example Generator: "I always remembered the last items of my shopping list better when my partner read them out to me over the phone, instead of me reading them off a written list."

Description: Mood-congruent memory bias: The improved recall of information congruent with one’s current mood.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll send this phishing email to the target in the form of a voice message, since they tend to remember things better when received via speech."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll send this phishing email to the target in the form of a voice message, since they tend to remember things better when received via speech."
General Example Generator: "I am only able to recall happy memories when I am in a good mood and can't recall any negative memories"

Description: Next-in-line effect: People taking turns speaking in a group tend to have diminished recall forthe words of others
Defender Example Generator: "I will try to manipulate the target's mood by sending them happy content, so they remember the message I want them to remember more accurately."
Attacker Example Generator: "I will try to manipulate the target's mood by sending them happy content, so they remember the message I want them to remember more accurately."
General Example Generator: "I can't remember what Jane said earlier, I was too focused on getting ready for my turn to speak."

Description: Part-list cueing effect: That being shown some items from a list and later retrieving one item causes it to become harder to retrieve the other items.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll wait until they're done speaking, I'll have a better chance of remembering what they said if I'm not next in line to speak."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll wait until they're done speaking, I'll have a better chance of remembering what they said if I'm not next in line to speak."
General Example Generator: I couldn't remember the rest of the list after he cued me with the first few items.

Description: Peak-end rule: That people seem to perceive not the sum of an experience but the average of how it was at its peak (e.g., pleasant or unpleasant) and how it ended.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll focus on exploiting the part-list cueing effect by only showing the target a few items on the list, they'll have a harder time remembering the other items I want them to overlook."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll focus on exploiting the part-list cueing effect by only showing the target a few items on the list, they'll have a harder time remembering the other items I want them to overlook."
General Example Generator: "I remember that vacation being really fun overall, but it's really the way it ended, with that amazing sunset and a delicious meal, that really stuck with me."

Description: Persistence: The unwanted recurrence of memories of a traumatic event.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll make sure to end the attack on a high note, so the target will remember the breach as less severe than it actually was."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll make sure to end the attack on a high note, so the target will remember the breach as less severe than it actually was."
General Example Generator: "I can't stop thinking about the accident, it keeps coming back to me even though I try to move on."

Description: Picture superiority effect: The notion that concepts that are learned by viewing pictures are more easily and frequently recalled than are concepts that are learned by viewing their written word form counterparts.
Defender Example Generator: "An attacker might exploit the persistence of a traumatic event by using social engineering tactics that trigger fear in their target to get them to comply with their demands."
Attacker Example Generator: "An attacker might exploit the persistence of a traumatic event by using social engineering tactics that trigger fear in their target to get them to comply with their demands."
General Example Generator: "I remember the street layout so much better when I studied it with the map, instead of just reading the names of the streets in a book"

Description: Positivity effect (Socioemotional selectivity theory): That older adults favor positive over negative information in their memories.
Defender Example Generator: "Phishing emails with images are more likely to be remembered and clicked on, as the picture superiority effect suggests that people recall information learned through images better than through text."
Attacker Example Generator: "Phishing emails with images are more likely to be remembered and clicked on, as the picture superiority effect suggests that people recall information learned through images better than through text."
General Example Generator: "I only remember the good times from my youth and have trouble remembering the negative experiences."

Description: Primacy effect, recency effect & serial position effect: That items near the end of a sequence are the easiest to recall, followed by the items at the beginning of a sequence; items in the middle are the least likely to be remembered.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll send this phishing email disguised as a happy event invitation, because older adults tend to remember positive information better and are more likely to fall for it."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll send this phishing email disguised as a happy event invitation, because older adults tend to remember positive information better and are more likely to fall for it."
General Example Generator: "I can remember the first and last items on the grocery list perfectly, but the middle items are a blur."

Description: Processing difficulty effect: That information that takes longer to read and is thought about more (processed with more difficulty) is more easily remembered.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll use a long and complicated password with special characters and numbers so that the defender will have a hard time processing it and they'll be less likely to remember it."
Attacker Example Generator: "I created a phishing email with several intentionally confusing statements, knowing that the increased processing difficulty would make the recipient more likely to remember the content and be more susceptible to clicking on the malicious links."
General Example Generator: "I remember that math problem I struggled with for an hour much better than the ones I breezed through in just a few minutes because the difficult one required more processing and mental effort."

Description: Reminiscence bump: The recalling of more personal events from adolescence and early adulthood than personal events from other lifetime periods.
Defender Example Generator: "By sending a targeted phishing email at the end of the day, the recipient is more likely to remember and fall for the scam, due to the recency effect."
Attacker Example Generator: "By sending a targeted phishing email at the end of the day, the recipient is more likely to remember and fall for the scam, due to the recency effect."
General Example Generator: "I can't believe I remembered that silly thing I did in high school but can't remember what I did last week."

Description: Rosy retrospection: The remembering of the past as having been better than it really was.
Defender Example Generator: "An attacker might try to exploit the reminiscence bump by sending phishing emails that appear to be from an old friend or associate from the target's adolescence or early adulthood."
Attacker Example Generator: "An attacker might try to exploit the reminiscence bump by sending phishing emails that appear to be from an old friend or associate from the target's adolescence or early adulthood."
General Example Generator: "I can't believe how great things used to be, I must have had it so easy back then."

Description: Self-relevance effect: That memories relating to the self are better recalled than similar information relating to others.
Defender Example Generator: "An attacker might use the rosy retrospection bias to trick a victim into thinking their past security measures were stronger than they actually were, making them less likely to suspect a current attack."
Attacker Example Generator: "An attacker might use the rosy retrospection bias to trick a victim into thinking their past security measures were stronger than they actually were, making them less likely to suspect a current attack."
General Example Generator: "I can't seem to recall what my friend said last week, but I remember every detail of my own conversation with her."

Description: Source confusion: Confusing episodic memories with other information, creating distorted memories.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll target the network administrator because they are likely to have better recall of their own login credentials than those of their colleagues."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll target the network administrator because they are likely to have better recall of their own login credentials than those of their colleagues."
General Example Generator: "I swear I read that article about the new housing development, but now that I think about it, I'm not sure if it was in the newspaper or on my friend's Facebook page."

Description: Spacing effect: That information is better recalled if exposure to it is repeated over a long span of time rather than a short one.
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker tricks the target into thinking that the fake source of information is the real source, causing the target to have false or distorted memories of the events."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker tricks the target into thinking that the fake source of information is the real source, causing the target to have false or distorted memories of the events."
General Example Generator: "I know I read this somewhere before, but I can't remember if it was on the news or in a book."

Description: Spotlight effect: The tendency to overestimate the amount that other people notice your appearance or behavior.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll make sure to repeatedly target this network over a long period of time so that the employees will be more likely to remember the phishing emails I send and fall for my attack."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll make sure to repeatedly target this network over a long period of time so that the employees will be more likely to remember the phishing emails I send and fall for my attack."
General Example Generator: "I can't believe everyone saw me trip and fall, I'm sure they're all talking about it."

Description: Stereotypical bias: Memory distorted towards stereotypes (e.g., racial or gender).
Defender Example Generator: "I'll send an email to the network administrator pretending to be their boss, since they'll think that their boss is the only one who would have noticed the mistake they made, they'll be more likely to fall for my phishing scam."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll send an email to the network administrator pretending to be their boss, since they'll think that their boss is the only one who would have noticed the mistake they made, they'll be more likely to fall for my phishing scam."
General Example Generator: "I'm sure the thief was a young black man, all the criminals in this area fit that description."

Description: Suffix effect: Diminishment of the recency effect because a sound item is appended to the list that the subject is not required to recall.
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker might use the target's preconceived notions about their race or gender to exploit their network, knowing that the target's memory may be distorted towards those stereotypes."
Attacker Example Generator: "The suffix effect could be used by an attacker to reduce the likelihood of the target remembering the malicious code, by appending benign code to the end of the attack script."
General Example Generator: "I remembered the first and last items on the list perfectly, but everything in the middle is just a blur, it's like the suffix at the end of the list ruined my recall."

Description: Suggestibility: A form of misattribution where ideas suggested by a questioner are mistaken for memory.
Defender Example Generator: "The suffix effect could be used by an attacker to reduce the likelihood of the target remembering the malicious code, by appending benign code to the end of the attack script."
Attacker Example Generator: "I was able to gain access to the network by suggesting to an employee that I was an IT support technician and needed their login credentials for maintenance, which they provided without question due to my suggestion."
General Example Generator: "I am convinced that the perpetrator had a tattoo on their arm, but now I realize that this detail might have been suggested by the police during questioning."

Description: Tachypsychia: When time perceived by the individual either lengthens, making events appear to slow down, or contracts.
Defender Example Generator: "By using social engineering tactics, I can convince the target to reveal confidential information by planting false memories and suggestions in their mind."
Attacker Example Generator: "By using social engineering tactics, I can convince the target to reveal confidential information by planting false memories and suggestions in their mind."
General Example Generator: "I swear it felt like that car crash happened in slow motion, but it couldn't have been more than a few seconds."

Description: Telescoping effect: The tendency to displace recent events backward in time and remote events forward in time, so that recent events appear more remote, and remote events, more recent.
Defender Example Generator: "I can use tachypsychia to my advantage by making the target believe that the attack is taking much longer than it actually is, causing them to become less vigilant and make mistakes."
Attacker Example Generator: "I can use tachypsychia to my advantage by making the target believe that the attack is taking much longer than it actually is, causing them to become less vigilant and make mistakes."
General Example Generator: "I'm sure that meeting with my boss happened last week, not three days ago."

Description: Testing effect: The fact that you more easily remember information you have read by rewriting it instead of rereading it.
Defender Example Generator: "The attacker uses the telescoping effect to make the victim believe that their recent password change was weeks ago, tricking them into thinking they need to change it again, which in turn gives the attacker access to the network."
Attacker Example Generator: "The attacker uses the telescoping effect to make the victim believe that their recent password change was weeks ago, tricking them into thinking they need to change it again, which in turn gives the attacker access to the network."
General Example Generator: "I can't believe I passed the exam, I only studied by rewriting my notes instead of rereading them, the testing effect really works!"

Description: Tip of the tongue phenomenon: When a subject is able to recall parts of an item, or related information, but is frustratingly unable to recall the whole item. This is thought to be an instance of “blocking” where multiple similar memories are being recalled and interfere with each other.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll make sure to make an effort to write down the login credentials instead of just reading it, because I know that the testing effect will help me remember it better."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll make sure to make an effort to write down the login credentials instead of just reading it, because I know that the testing effect will help me remember it better."
General Example Generator: "I know I've heard of that actor before, but it's on the tip of my tongue and I can't remember their name right now."

Description: Travis Syndrome: Overestimating the significance of the present.
Defender Example Generator: "I know the password I used before, but it's on the tip of my tongue, and I can't seem to recall the whole thing, maybe it's just interference from similar passwords I've used before."
Attacker Example Generator: "I know the password I used before, but it's on the tip of my tongue, and I can't seem to recall the whole thing, maybe it's just interference from similar passwords I've used before."
General Example Generator: "I know I'm gonna remember this moment forever, it's the most important moment of my life"

Description: Verbatim effect: That the “gist” of what someone has said is better remembered than the verbatim wording.
Defender Example Generator: "I'm sure this new vulnerability I found is the one that will allow me to compromise the entire network, I'm not leaving this machine until I exploit it."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'm sure this new vulnerability I found is the one that will allow me to compromise the entire network, I'm not leaving this machine until I exploit it."
General Example Generator: "I can't remember his exact words, but I remember the general idea of what he said."

Description: von Restorff effect: That an item that sticks out is more likely to be remembered than other items.
Defender Example Generator: "I won't need to remember the exact words the target said, I just need to know the general idea they conveyed."
Attacker Example Generator: "I won't need to remember the exact words the target said, I just need to know the general idea they conveyed."
General Example Generator: "I always remember the blue shirt in the store because it stood out among the other colors"

Description: Zeigarnik effect: That uncompleted or interrupted tasks are remembered better than completed ones.
Defender Example Generator: "I'll make sure this network sticks out by using a unique malware, it's more likely to be remembered and easily recognized if we need to get back in again later."
Attacker Example Generator: "I'll make sure this network sticks out by using a unique malware, it's more likely to be remembered and easily recognized if we need to get back in again later."
